title: SB 1.18.12 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 02-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: You are distributing nectar of the lotus feet of Govinda, the Supreme Lord. And that is very pleasing to us.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam 1.18.12, explaining that the sages of Naimisharanya are glorifying Suta Goswami for distributing the nectar of the lotus feet of Govinda.

segments.key_quote: Fruitive activity means doing an activity the result of which we are doing an activity which is some type of material benefit or material enjoyment.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts fruitive activities, which aim for material benefits, with activities that lead to spiritual progress, emphasizing that fruitive sacrifices in this age are prone to imperfections and may not yield spiritual results.

segments.key_quote: The sacrificial fire kindled by the sages of Naimisha Aranya was certainly full of smoke and doubts because of so many flaws.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that sacrifices performed in Kali Yuga are often flawed due to the scarcity of qualified Brahmanas and that any discrepancy can spoil the entire sacrifice, making the results uncertain.

segments.key_quote: Performance of any kind of sacrifice in this age of Kali is also uncertain.
segments.summary: The speaker draws an analogy between agricultural enterprises dependent on rain and sacrifices in Kali Yuga, highlighting the uncertainty of results due to factors beyond human control, particularly the lack of qualified Brahmanas.

segments.key_quote: In Kali Yuga it is particularly recommended that one should perform only one type of Yajna. What is that? The Sankirtan Yajna.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that in Kali Yuga, the recommended sacrifice is Sankirtan Yajna, the congregational chanting of the holy name, due to the scarcity of qualified Brahmanas and the ineffectiveness of fruitive sacrifices.

segments.key_quote: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu has blessed all the fallen souls of this world that you please chant Hare Krishna in Sankirtana and you will achieve all perfection just by doing this.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Sankirtan doesn't require qualification and is accessible to everyone due to the mercy of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, and that the sages of Naimisharanya were experiencing the positive effects of hearing from Suta Goswami.

segments.key_quote: Before even they can begin hearing the actual Srimad Bhagavatam these sages are perceiving the result of the quality of that hearing.
segments.summary: The speaker notes that even before Suta Goswami begins reciting the actual Srimad Bhagavatam, the sages are already experiencing the nectar-like quality of hearing about Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Anyone who hears Krishna Katha from the right source, they immediately are able to perceive this result of hearing Krishna Katha.
segments.summary: The speaker compares the experience of devotional service to the satisfaction of eating when hungry, emphasizing that the results of hearing Krishna Katha are directly and practically perceived, leading to spiritual realization through Sankirtan Yajna.

segments.key_quote: Definitely the sages of Naimisharanya were fortunate to meet Suta Goswami and hear from Suta Goswami, the Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that the sages of Naimisharanya were fortunate to hear Krishna Katha from Suta Goswami, experiencing the positive effects that contrasted with the doubts and suffering from their sacrificial fire.
